page.title: 03Agriculture in 19th century
page.content: all owners of land and all ratepayers had a duty to provide for paupers who according to nineteenth century opinion reached this position because of drunkeness, old age, feeble mindedness, improvident marriages or casual labour. For Trecastle another factor must have been the agricultural depression. The 1879 harvest in Britain was purported to be the worst of the century. From 1875 to 1884 there was a combination of cold springs and rainy summers, and later drought and cattle disease. The price of wheat fell from Â£2.20 a quarter in 1875 to 87.5p a quarter in 1894. According to the Tithes information the main cereals were wheat, barley and oats. Barley was probably kept for the feeding of pigs and cattle and oats for feeding horses. According to J.G.
